questions.text: A 44-year-old woman comes to the physician for the evaluation of right knee pain for 1 week. The pain began after the patient twisted her knee during basketball practice. At the time of the injury, she felt a popping sensation and her knee became swollen over the next few hours. The pain is exacerbated by walking up or down stairs and worsens throughout the day. She also reports occasional locking of the knee. She has been taking acetaminophen during the past week, but the pain is worse today. Her mother has rheumatoid arthritis. The patient is 155 cm (4 ft 11 in) tall and weighs 75 kg (165 lb); BMI is 33 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows effusion of the right knee; range of motion is limited by pain. There is medial joint line tenderness. Knee extension with rotation results in an audible snap. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following?

choices.text: Joint space narrowing and sclerotic changes on x-ray
Hyperintense line in the meniscus on MRI
Erosions and synovial hyperplasia on MRI

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Joint space narrowing and sclerotic changes (along with osteophytes and subchondral cysts) are characteristic x-ray findings in patients with osteoarthritis (OA), which most commonly affects the knee. Although osteoarthritis, for which this patient is at risk (obese, middle-aged), is a common cause of knee pain that is exacerbated by walking up or down stairs and worsens throughout the day, it causes chronic pain and is not commonly associated with a locking sensation during movements. A large or complex meniscal injury that is left untreated or treated inadequately is a risk factor for the development of future osteoarthritis of the knee.

B) CORRECT:

A hyperintense line in the meniscus on MRI is diagnostic of meniscal tear. MRI is the first-line imaging test to identify and assess the extent of meniscal tears.

Arthroscopy is the definitive diagnostic test for meniscal tear, but it is invasive, so arthroscopy is rarely used to make an initial diagnosis of meniscal tear. Instead, arthroscopy is therapeutic in patients with MRI evidence of meniscal tear who have an indication for surgery (e.g., failed conservative therapy, joint instability, or a complex meniscal tear).
Image Description:

MRI knee (upper image: T1-weighted, coronal plane; lower image: T1-weighted, sagittal plane)

There is horizontal linear intermediate signal (white outline), parallel to the tibial plateau, within the posterior horn of the medial meniscus (green overlay).

This is consistent with a horizontal meniscal tear.

Red overlay: anterior horn of the medial meniscus

C) INCORRECT:

Medial joint laxity suggests medial collateral ligament (MCL) injury, which is the most common ligamentous knee injury. High-grade tears of the MCL commonly manifest with a concomitant injury to the anterior cruciate ligament or the medial meniscus. Although MCL injury can cause acute posttraumatic knee pain and manifest with medial joint line tenderness, it typically occurs after valgus stress (sometimes with external rotation) and significant effusion would be uncommon. Additionally, patients with MCL injury typically feel as though their knee is “giving out” rather than locking.

D) INCORRECT:

Anterior tibial translation (e.g., anterior drawer sign or Lachman sign) is consistent with anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) injury, which is a common sports injury involving twisting mechanisms and can cause posttraumatic knee pain. However, ACL injuries cause rapid knee effusion from hemarthrosis (due to the significant vascularity of the ligament) and are not associated with a locking sensation or popping/clicking on examination. ACL injuries are usually associated with significant knee instability, and patients often complain of the knee “giving out.” Instead, this patient had a gradual knee effusion, is able to walk, and her knee movement is associated with popping and locking.
Image Description:

MRI knee (STIR; sagittal view)

The anterior cruciate ligament is discontinuous. The distal part of the ligament demonstrates normal hypointense signal (red overlay), but the proximal half ligament demonstrates heterogenous hyperintense signal (yellow overlay). There is a gap between these two areas. There is also a large suprapatellar joint effusion (demonstrated as a white area due to high signal intensity; blue overlay). The partially imaged posterior cruciate ligament (green overlay) appears intact.

This is an example of an anterior cruciate ligament rupture. The gap between the proximal and distal half of the ligament indicates it is a full-thickness tear. The heterogeneous hyperintense signal of the proximal half indicates partial thickness tearing of that component.

E) INCORRECT:

Erosions and synovial hyperplasia are late findings of rheumatoid arthritis (RA), for which this patient is at risk given that she is a middle-aged female with a positive family history. RA can manifest with joint pain and effusion, but it is associated with chronic joint pain and inflammation (often involving multiple joints; classically the metacarpophalangeal and proximal interphalangeal joints) and does not occur acutely following trauma. Classically, RA symptoms are worst in the morning (i.e., morning stiffness for > 30 min) and improve throughout the day, whereas this patient's symptoms worsened throughout the day. Additionally, even in aggressive cases of RA, it often takes months to years until erosions become evident on imaging.

F) INCORRECT:

Posterior tibial translation (positive posterior drawer test) is indicative of posterior cruciate ligament (PCL) injury, which can cause sudden onset of posttraumatic knee pain. However, PCL injury is rare and typically caused by hyperflexion of the knee with a plantarflexed foot and causes rapid knee effusion (due to the significant vascularity of the ligament). In addition, it is associated with neither medial joint line tenderness nor popping/clicking/locking.
questions.hint: Given the acute onset knee pain with a history of locking and popping, joint line tenderness, and a positive McMurray test, a meniscal tear is the most likely diagnosis.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of acute onset left knee pain. The pain started while playing basketball after suddenly hearing a popping sound. He has been unable to run since this incident. He has exercise-induced asthma and allergic rhinitis. His only medication is a salbutamol inhaler. The patient appears healthy and well-nourished. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 67/min, and blood pressure is 120/80 mm Hg. Examination of the left knee shows lateral joint line tenderness. Total knee extension is not possible and a clicking sound is heard when the knee is extended and internally rotated. An x-ray of the left knee shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

MRI is the first-line imaging test to identify and assess the extent of meniscal tears, showing a hyperintense line in the meniscus with possible distorted meniscal morphology. Treatment depends on the extent of the injury and the patient's age. Conservative therapy with rest, ice, and elevation of the affected limb, along with analgesia and physical therapy (to strengthen the quadriceps muscle) is usually appropriate for simple tears in patients with preexisting degenerative changes in the knee joint. Indications for arthroscopic repair include complex meniscus tears and severe persistent functional impairment.
Image Description:

MRI knee (upper image: T1-weighted, coronal plane; lower image: T1-weighted, sagittal plane)

There is horizontal linear intermediate signal (white outline), parallel to the tibial plateau, within the posterior horn of the medial meniscus (green overlay).

This is consistent with a horizontal meniscal tear.

Red overlay: anterior horn of the medial meniscus

B) INCORRECT:

Reassurance and follow-up are alone inappropriate in this young, active patient with symptoms suggestive of a meniscal injury. Most meniscal tears heal poorly and will worsen with weight-bearing and physical activity. The absence of an intact meniscus would also predispose this patient to early osteoarthritis. Small (< 5 mm), stable, asymptomatic meniscal tears in the peripheral red zone (vascularized region), as well as degenerative meniscal tears in elderly individuals, can be treated nonoperatively with initial restriction of knee movement, followed by physical rehabilitation and follow-up.

C) INCORRECT:

Although the most likely diagnosis in this patient is meniscal injury, other conditions that manifest similarly (e.g., an intraarticular loose body due to osteochondritis dissecans) should be ruled out before surgery. The exact site and extent of meniscal injury, as well as the presence of other associated injuries (e.g., ligamentous injury), need to be determined before considering meniscal repair. Moreover, open knee surgery to visualize and/or repair the meniscus is inappropriate when less invasive diagnostic and therapeutic modalities are available. Open meniscal repair may be performed when meniscal injury is associated with fractures of the articular surfaces of the distal femur or proximal tibia, or in the case of severe knee dislocation. However, such are not commonly seen following sports traumas but typically only occur as a result of high-energy trauma (e.g., road traffic accidents, fall from a height).

D) INCORRECT:

Arthroscopy can be both diagnostic and therapeutic for meniscal tears. However, it is an invasive procedure that is reserved for diagnosis if less invasive diagnostic modalities are contraindicated.

E) INCORRECT:

Arthrocentesis is most commonly indicated in patients with suspected joint infection or gout. Both these conditions usually manifest with joint erythema and warmth, along with severe joint tenderness on palpation and severe restriction of knee joint movement. This patient presents with lateral joint line tenderness and a mild restriction in knee extension without any joint erythema or warmth, making the diagnoses of joint infection or gout unlikely. In the case of meniscal injury, arthrocentesis may be performed if severe hemarthrosis occurs. In such a setting, arthrocentesis would provide quick symptomatic relief until surgery could be performed. However, this patient does not have a joint effusion on physical examination that would be typical of severe hemarthrosis.
questions.hint: This patient presents with acute knee pain, lateral joint line tenderness, restricted knee extension, and a clicking sound on extension and internal rotation (positive McMurray test), which suggests lateral meniscus injury.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old man presents with a right-knee injury. Three days earlier, while playing Ultimate Frisbee after work, he caught a Frisbee in mid-air, landed, and then turned to throw the Frisbee behind him with his foot planted. He felt some strain but finished the game. In the next 24 hours, he experienced increasing pain in his right knee. He did not initially have swelling but has noticed some recently. He has been unable to kneel down or squat since the injury. He has not tried any over-the-counter medications for pain.
Physical examination reveals a trace to moderate right-knee effusion and joint-line tenderness along the medial side. Flexion is limited to about 120 degrees (compared with 140 degrees on the contralateral side), and extension is full. Anterior and posterior drawer signs are negative. The patient has palpable clicking and pain along the medial joint line when the knee is flexed while the foot is externally rotated (McMurray maneuver).
Anteroposterior and lateral radiographs of the right knee reveal no abnormalities.
Which one of the following management approaches is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Skyline radiograph of the right knee

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A skyline radiograph of the knee is most useful for diagnosing osteoarthritis or malalignment of the patellofemoral joint, both of which are chronic conditions. The conventional anteroposterior and lateral views should be sufficient to rule out fracture in a patient with lateral or medial knee pain.

B) INCORRECT:

Arthrocentesis is unnecessary in assessing a traumatic injury. Synovial fluid analysis is warranted when an effusion is associated with pain, erythema, or fever in the absence of known trauma.

C) INCORRECT:

Indications for MRI and referral to orthopedic surgery include severe symptoms (inability to bear weight after injury, joint instability, significant locking of the joint) or evidence of concomitant ligamentous injury on examination. Persistent knee pain and swelling for longer than 2 weeks on conservative management also merits further evaluation.

D) CORRECT:

Trauma to the knee during sports can cause either ligamentous or meniscal injury. The value of physical examination maneuvers varies with the structure being tested. Assessment of the anterior and posterior cruciate ligaments by the Lachman test and anterior and posterior drawer signs has high predictive value. In contrast, exam maneuvers for diagnosing meniscal tears, such as the McMurray maneuver, have low sensitivity but good specificity. Management strategies directed purely at symptom relief are appropriate to treat most minor soft-tissue injuries.

Key learning point: The appropriate treatment for a trauma-induced minor meniscal tear is analgesia, such as nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drug therapy.

E) INCORRECT:

An intra-articular glucocorticoid injection is appropriate for treating noninfectious inflammatory arthritis or for temporary pain relief in degenerative joint disease.

questions.text:
A 46-year-old man presents for evaluation of left knee pain, which began one week ago while he was playing basketball. He was able to walk with assistance immediately after the pain began, and he now walks on his own, but he has noticed clicking in the left knee with movement, as well as intermittent locking of the left knee.
His vital signs are normal. The left knee has no local tenderness, effusion, warmth, or erythema. He is able to fully extend the left knee but experiences pain. While standing on his left leg with it flexed to 20 degrees, he experiences pain with rotation of the body over the knee joint. When he is supine and maximally flexing the left hip and knee while abducting the knee and externally rotating the left foot, passive extension of the left knee does not reproduce pain or elicit a palpable snap. The knee is stable with anterior and posterior stress maneuvers, as well as varus and valgus stress testing.
What is the best next step for this patient?

choices.text: Referral to orthopedics for surgical evaluation
Intra-articular injection of a viscoelastic solution

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A glucocorticoid injection would not be recommended here; it is typically reserved for patients who have underlying osteoarthritis complicated by a chronic degenerative meniscal tear.

B) INCORRECT:

MRI is the most sensitive imaging modality to detect meniscal tears. However, incidental findings are common, and detection of a meniscal tear on MRI rarely alters management; thus, MRI is generally not necessary unless surgery is being considered or symptoms persist after conservative treatment.

C) INCORRECT:

Consultation with an orthopedic surgeon is advisable if the knee is locked or if there are persistent symptoms such as knee effusion or frequent painful locking after conservative treatment.

D) CORRECT:

A presumptive diagnosis of a meniscal tear can often be made on the basis of certain features, including the mechanism of the injury (usually a twisting injury, sometimes with a popping or tearing sensation), characteristic symptoms (catching, locking, or pain with particular movements), and features on the physical examination, such as joint-line tenderness and positive provocative tests (e.g., McMurray or Thessaly test) without evidence of ligamentous instability. The history is important because physical examination findings have marginal predictive value; in contrast, physical examination findings are more helpful for ruling out a simultaneous tear of the anterior cruciate ligament. Swelling after a meniscal injury typically occurs insidiously over 24 hours after the event, if at all, as opposed to the immediate pain and swelling often seen in ligamentous injuries.

Symptoms from minor meniscal injuries often resolve spontaneously, without definite long-term consequences. Previously, arthroscopic partial meniscectomy to repair meniscal tears was widely recommended and among the most common orthopedic procedures, but several randomized studies failed to show any benefit of this surgery compared with sham surgery or physical therapy.

In the absence of hemarthrosis or gross instability, the recommended initial treatment of a meniscal injury is conservative therapy with rest, ice, and use of crutches if needed. Physical therapy should then follow with the goal of strengthening the quadriceps and hamstring muscles to provide support to the joint.

Key learning point: A twisting injury to the knee that results in catching and locking of the knee is most likely to be an injury to the meniscus.

E) INCORRECT:

Injection of a viscoelastic solution would not be expected to provide any relief to a patient with features of a meniscal tear.

questions.text:
A 14-year-old boy reports painful clicking and locking of the left knee for the past several months. He is an avid basketball player but does not recall any specific injury or inciting event.
On examination, he has full range of motion of the knee, and he has no pain or laxity with stress of the collateral ligaments. Extending the knee from full flexion, while tibial internal rotation and varus force are applied, elicits a painful click.
A plain-film radiograph shows a widened lateral joint space and squaring of the lateral femoral condyle, with no fracture or bony abnormality appreciated (figure).
In addition to referral to orthopedics, which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Immobilization in a hinged knee brace, locked at 15 degrees

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although CT would allow for further evaluation of bony structure, the details of this case suggest meniscal pathology, which is better evaluated by MRI.

B) CORRECT:

Painful locking, catching, or popping of the knee should raise concern for meniscal pathology. On examination, this patient has painful clicking upon extension of a fully flexed knee with application of tibial internal rotation and varus force (otherwise known as a McMurray test), which suggests meniscal involvement. The radiographic findings of a widened lateral joint space and squaring of the lateral femoral condyle suggest the presence of a discoid meniscus.

A discoid meniscus is an anatomical variant in meniscal shape characterized by central hypertrophy and enlarged diameter. Typically, the lateral meniscus is involved. Approximately 3% to 5% of the population has a discoid meniscus, and 25% of cases have bilateral involvement. Patients may remain asymptomatic, but the discoid shape is prone to tearing and instability from abnormal mechanical forces. Tears and instability can occur without an obvious injury, most commonly in adolescence. Radiographs are often normal, but they can show a widening of the lateral joint space, squaring of the lateral femoral condyle, or cupping of the lateral tibial plateau.

Choosing Appropriate Management in This Case

The most appropriate next step for this patient with mechanical symptoms is MRI, which allows for visualization of the meniscal shape and detection and characterization of any tears.

• If instability or tearing of the meniscus is identified on cross-sectional imaging, arthroscopic partial meniscectomy and saucerization may be indicated. This procedure involves debridement of the damaged meniscus and removal of the central portion of discoid tissue in an attempt to create normal morphology.
• If no instability or tearing is identified, physical therapy would be appropriate.

Key learning point: Painful clicking or locking of a knee suggests meniscal pathology, which should be evaluated with MRI.

C) INCORRECT:

If no instability or tearing is identified after MRI, physical therapy would be appropriate.

D) INCORRECT:

Glucocorticoid injection would not address this patient’s mechanical symptoms and is typically reserved for older patients in the setting of arthritis.

E) INCORRECT:

Immobilization of the knee would not address meniscal injury and can contribute to deconditioning of the surrounding musculature.

questions.text: A 25-year-old basketball player presents with right knee pain that began 3 days ago during a game when he pivoted on his planted foot. He reports intermittent catching and locking sensations when walking. Physical examination shows joint line tenderness and a positive patellar tap test. McMurray test produces an audible click with external rotation during knee extension. Knee x-rays show no fractures. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Initiate conservative management with rest and knee brace

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Additional provocative tests are not necessary when a clinical diagnosis has already been established. The patient has a positive McMurray test, effusion, and characteristic clinical features. Further testing would not change management at this point.

B) INCORRECT:

MRI is the imaging modality of choice for meniscus tears but is typically indicated for athletic adults under 40 years of age with posttraumatic locked knee after clinical evaluation or for persistent symptoms after 4–6 weeks of conservative management.

C) INCORRECT:

Arthroscopy is both diagnostic and therapeutic but is generally reserved for patients with persistent symptoms, inner zone tears, and functional limitations after conservative management. Arthroscopy is not the initial treatment approach for acute meniscus tears.

D) CORRECT:

Correct -- A clinical diagnosis of meniscus tear can be made when multiple provocative tests are positive, knee joint effusion is present, and knee x-rays are normal. Conservative management including knee brace, rest, leg elevation, and analgesia is typically appropriate for simple tears.

E) INCORRECT:

Formal musculoskeletal ultrasound has similar accuracy to MRI but is not necessary when the clinical diagnosis has already been established. The positive patellar tap test already confirms joint effusion, and provocative tests are positive.

questions.text: A 22-year-old collegiate soccer player comes to an urgent care clinic with left knee pain after an injury during a match yesterday. He states he planted his foot and twisted, feeling an immediate 'pop.' He now experiences pain, swelling, and a sensation of his knee 'catching' when he tries to fully extend it. Physical examination shows moderate joint effusion and distinct tenderness over the lateral joint line. The McMurray test elicits a painful click with internal rotation of the tibia. Lachman and varus stress tests are negative. Which of the following is the most appropriate study to confirm the suspected diagnosis?

choices.text: Anteroposterior and lateral radiographs of the knee
Computed tomography arthrography of the knee
Magnetic resonance imaging of the knee

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Ultrasound is useful for evaluating superficial structures, effusions, and some ligaments and tendons around the knee. However, it has a limited ability to visualize the entire meniscus, particularly the posterior horns, due to poor acoustic penetration through bone. It is highly operator-dependent and is not the standard imaging modality for confirming a suspected meniscal tear.

B) INCORRECT:

Radiographs are the appropriate initial imaging study for many acute knee injuries to evaluate for fractures or significant joint malalignment. However, they cannot visualize soft tissues such as the menisci or ligaments. Because the clinical suspicion for a meniscal tear is high and a fracture is unlikely in this patient, radiographs are not the definitive study to confirm the diagnosis.

C) INCORRECT:

CT arthrography, which involves injecting contrast into the joint followed by a CT scan, can visualize intra-articular structures. However, a different study offers superior soft-tissue contrast and detail for evaluating meniscal and ligamentous injuries without using ionizing radiation.

D) CORRECT:

Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is the noninvasive gold standard for diagnosing intra-articular soft-tissue injuries of the knee. It provides excellent detail of the menisci, ligaments, articular cartilage, and bone marrow. For a suspected meniscal tear, an MRI can confirm the diagnosis, define the location and type of tear (e.g., bucket handle, radial), and identify any associated injuries such as ligament sprains or bone bruises. This detailed information is crucial for determining the appropriate management, whether conservative or surgical.

E) INCORRECT:

Although arthroscopy allows for direct visualization and is the definitive method for both diagnosing and treating meniscal tears, it is an invasive surgical procedure. It is considered a therapeutic intervention rather than a first-line diagnostic study. Noninvasive imaging is performed first to confirm the pathology and plan for a potential surgical repair, which is performed arthroscopically.
questions.hint: This patient's presentation of a twisting injury, joint line tenderness, and mechanical symptoms such as 'catching' raises suspicion for a meniscal tear.
